reviews.review_msg: This professor is nice, but the course is unorganized; we get almost no feedback for assignments, the lectures are unengaging, and he reads off the slides. The grading is a bit questionable, no rubric and it lowkey feels like he makes the grades we get up. The bright side is that the class has zero workload, and you just write papers sometimes.

Terrible lectures. Said the department got mad for him marking too high last term. Everything given to all 60 students was in a range of 72 to 83  everytime. Provided no feedback and graded for his own goal. B+ for participation as the most active person in my tutorial, which would have got me an A- if slightly higher. A careless and corrupt prof.

Unorganized, not engaging in lectures, difficult to communicate with. I was lowered a partial letter grade immediately before the final grade submission through a re-grade of a short written assignment from early in the semester, refused to explain choice and suggested I file an appeal, prevented my first and only 4.0 term. Similar issues all term

Lectures are dry, he reads off text-heavy slides which gives little incentive to attend. He gives no rubric or feedback as to why he docks marks on assignments, and everyone pretty much gets the same grade to maintain the B- average. When asked, he tells students they should have dropped the course if getting good grades is their priority.

really nice guy! Readings were quite lengthy every week but it was super interesting. He's an easy marker which
got him trouble with the board for making the class average too high though.
GPA booster with this guy. A little bit unorganized but he is a very easy marker.

Really a nice prof!! he gave clear and organized lectures.  the three document analyses and exams were all cover in his lecture.  attend every lecture and take notes on he slides then you will be fine with exams and assignments.

Probably the best prof i ever had in SFU, but ironically, he isn't originally a SFU prof. I finally learned about "China" after taking his class for two terms. His teaching really makes me think, and explains perfectly what makes China "China" today. I would definitely register in UBC and continue to take his class. Green is simply the BEST!

Superb prof. Good prep, and he's passionate about what he does. He's an excellent speaker and really keeps your attention. Really knows his stuff, also fluent in Mandarin Chinese, and can explain why it's called Mandarin :D

Terrific prof. He's a bit nervous, doesn't quite know how to handle students yet (this is only his first year). Knowledgeable, interesting, clear, and a really nice guy. He may cast furtive looks at the door while he's talking to you - learn to love it.
strongly agree the previous comments!!!

his lec is useless not even related to the textbook and ur essay!weekly summaries worth 1% but he mark u by 100 and give u 40/100 orz he doesnt let u use the information found online for a 20 pages essay keep changing his syllabus(presentations added) u need to read 100+ pages every week! suck at eng!ppt r useless! worst prof ever seen!!REALLY !!

This prof is NOT professional cuz he has been late to class for the last 3 weeks of class. He doens't know how to set up the PP slides and needs to call for Tech support almost every week. Can't speak eng clearly and rush through lecture. Just tell u to read the books, which means you'll get 100+ pages per week! It's such a pain sitting in class!!
One of the greatest history professors at SFU! Strongly recommend taking this class with him. Make sure to participate and do the readings! He also makes his lectures very interesting!

Professor Brown is one of the best profs in the history department! His lectures were fun to listen to and very interesting. The class only had three essays and also had four in class mini assignments. Make sure to participate as it is worth 23% of your grade and do the readings before tutorial. I Strongly recommend taking this class!
excellent prof for chinese history. he is very knowledgeable and his lectures are clear and interesting from beginning to end. don't be late for class though!

(Continuing)His notes list the important points (periods, people, policies, perspectives and events) instead of cover everything, which means you need to listen carefully in the lecture, especially when he slow down. Weekly assignments are very useful and , which make you won't feel nervous before exams. His quizzes and exams are (To be continued)

I took HIST254 with him this Fall Term(2012),he is brilliant professor. Thanks to his patient explanation towards history periods and clear analysis towards historical periods, I got 87 out of 100. He is very knowledgeable, insightful, minded and humorous, and and he never merely repeat what the textbook said. (To be continued)
great prof

Lecture material and courseware readings are crucial to doing well on the exam. It's important to attend every tutorial for this very reason. You'll learn critical information you can use in your exam responses. He aims to have his students think outside the box and analyze information carefully. If you can provide insight, you'll do well.

Very knowledgable in his field of studies. Exam questions and marking are very fair. Pretty easy course if you attend his lectures. Text book isn't entirely useful, focus more on couseware. His points are very clear, and emphaises a lot on testable material. Funny, and interesting lectures. Remebers your name if you approach him. Highly recommeded!
OMG! tis prof is the BEST prof on campus! just dont be late though

If you're not serious about the topic & just want a prof that remembers your name, Brown is your man. Otherwise, avoid!  Knows nothing about early Chinese hist. Can't support his own, sometimes ridiculous, statements. Vacuous lectures, naive platitudes, high school level assignments & childish rules like docking marks if your cell rings in class.
good teacher, but i hate his tutorial, lotz of reading before each tutorial

This class was fun. He's very enthusiastic about teaching the class. He loves what he's doing and is pretty funny. Participation in tutorials is 22% in total (11 sessions). If you just go and not talk for every session, the most you'll get is 11%. Midterm was 18% and was out of 18, which I found unfair. Lots of reading for the course.

I LOVED this class! I have no prior desire or interest to take any history course, let alone a Chinese history course. Prof. Brown was by far the best professor I have EVER had at SFU. He is so approchable and helpful. He takes the time to get to know everyone in the class (all 120 of them). His lectures are interactive and excitting. Great course!

Super awesome prof. make sure you show up readings done (there not that hard, and very interesting), on time, no cell phones. He is a good speaker, and remembers everyone's names, and i mean EVERYONE's

If every professor were like Brown, I'd get straight A's not because the material is easy but because the teaching and the style of his courses are amazing. I've never been more engaged in a class. I had no interest in China prior to this class, and I still loved the course.

Wow! I LOVE this professor. He is so amazing. His office hours consist of sitting at Renaissance coffee and chatting with his students. He knows EVERYONE's name in the lecture hall (That's 102 student). His TA's are well trained, the course material is easy and very engaging. 1 complaint: wasn't a fan of his midterm of only 18 marks for 18 percent.

A VERY good prof, and interesting class. Knows what he is doing and very organized! There are however a great amount of readings to do each week, but if you are able to keep up with it you will be fine!
BEST PROF EVER!!!
Good professor!!!!!! She is amazing!!!!!  Although I had a tough time through the semester, she gives me a really grade. She is pretty kind and helpful!!!!!  I would like to take her course again!!!

One of the worst professors I ever had. He insisted on an entirely different essay format from any other prof in the History department. He weighted sentence structure as heavily as content in his marking scheme and never gave clear constructive criticism as to how to improve. His lectures were interesting however they were not helpful for tests.

Okay prof, with some humour. I took His 254 - Chinese history before 1800 - with him in the 2007 winter semester. His teaching style and notes are very unorganized, plus he doesn't curve, it is somewhat difficult to get a good grade i.e. above 80 (A-). Nevertheless, he is an okay prof.

Very energetic teacher, U'll need to get lots of clarity on assignments, expects almost flawless grammar on assignments, a really good tutorial leader, expects lots of participation from students, lectures are somewhat disorganized but interesting, makes for difficult note taking. Course texts and readings were not well matched with his lectures.
An excellent Prof I have ever met ! He is so helpful and nice ~ always have fun in his class ~ I become love History after I attended in his class ! Highly recommand !

AWESOME prof! Makes the class truly engaging and worthwhile of attending. Is super enthusiastic and helpful both in-class and one on one. Responds to emails promptly and gives very detailed explanations and overall tries to help you as much as he could. Overall super enjoyable class - highly recommended!

He is a nice & helpful guy. BUT, he is a VERY HARD MARKER. If u can't get A in english course then DO NOT take him. PLUS, u have to expect a VERY heavy course load. BESIDES, he just speaks out every point in class, non-stop!! No Lecture notes. Only notes given are the TITLES of what he's gonna say.
Dr. Clossey is an excellent prof.  His enthusiasm in unmatched in SFU.  Assignments are fun and thoughtfully marked.
